The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency provides funds to each State for education on health effects of environmental tobacco smoke on children. States receive funds based on population ratio and must use them for relevant activities. The Administrator ensures that each State receives a minimum of 0.5% and a maximum of 2.5% of available funds for grants related to tobacco smoke exposure education. Additionally, funds are allocated for a national education campaign on minimizing tobacco smoke exposure effects on individuals. The Administrator establishes a campaign to minimize children's exposure to environmental tobacco smoke in the home and coordinates activities with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and other Federal agencies. Funding for research and peer review studies on tobacco smoke exposure is provided through amounts from a Trust Fund established as part of a national settlement on tobacco litigation. The section allocates funding for various subsections, including $185,000,000 for subsection (a), $10,000,000 for subsection (b), and $5,000,000 for subsection (c) annually. The provision expires after 25 years from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. PREEMPTION. The provisions of this Act shall not preempt any State or local law with greater restrictions. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF FEDERAL BUILDINGS. The provisions of Executive Order 13058 apply to all federal government facilities and outdoor areas under its control. Enforcement is carried out by the head of the relevant federal agency, the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, or other appropriate authorities. The provisions of Executive Order 13058 apply to all federal government facilities and outdoor areas under its control, enforced by relevant federal agency heads, the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, and the Congressional Office of Compliance. PROHIBITIONS AGAINST SMOKING ON SCHEDULED FLIGHTS. Prohibitions against smoking on scheduled flights are outlined in Section 41706 of title 49, United States Code. It prohibits smoking on scheduled airline flights in interstate and intrastate air transportation. The Secretary of Transportation mandates all air carriers to prohibit smoking on flights within or outside the United States. Foreign air carriers must also comply with these smoking prohibitions. The smoking prohibitions on scheduled flights, as outlined in Section 41706 of title 49, United States Code, apply only to the passenger cabin and lavatory of aircraft operated by foreign air carriers. The Secretary of Transportation will prescribe necessary regulations for enforcement. The effective date of this amendment will be 60 days after the enactment of the Act.
